## 

<span key="8d051df2d27c4003aa244f35661fb2a3"><span offset-key="8d051df2d27c4003aa244f35661fb2a3:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#what-is-redux" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="7c5b6abda46d4a81a5584a2006754e06" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="0e33162d0b374feaac1336e86520348e"><span data-offset-key="0e33162d0b374feaac1336e86520348e:0">What is Redux?</span></span></span></a><span key="97c88fef40b24cff8e2b7f3e77595326"><span offset-key="97c88fef40b24cff8e2b7f3e77595326:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="e09dc138db4a42fcb1bb0a1f3895fd0c"><span offset-key="e09dc138db4a42fcb1bb0a1f3895fd0c:0">It helps to understand what this "Redux" thing is in the first place. What does it do? What problems does it help me solve? Why would I want to use it?</span></span>

<span key="a77444d6f2674518a34bceb5421fb44c">**Redux is a pattern and library for managing and updating application state, using events called "actions".**<span offset-key="a77444d6f2674518a34bceb5421fb44c:1"> It serves as a centralized store for state that needs to be used across your entire application, with rules ensuring that the state can only be updated in a predictable fashion.</span></span>

### 

<span key="c9f367b4d8c84861b932a57bad82583b"><span offset-key="c9f367b4d8c84861b932a57bad82583b:0">Why Should I Use Redux?</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#why-should-i-use-redux" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="470b3ca6c89b4091ac7325f1e20deeff" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="bf773826de48458ea4734d127b7cd1c5"><span data-offset-key="bf773826de48458ea4734d127b7cd1c5:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="b32bd3fe37b644e59150704000a24c08"><span offset-key="b32bd3fe37b644e59150704000a24c08:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="ca495d056f2243c4af4087037a476457"><span offset-key="ca495d056f2243c4af4087037a476457:0">Redux helps you manage "global" state - state that is needed across many parts of your application.</span></span>

<span key="54d9d5bb321a4f58a4eaf2961f2ac859">**The patterns and tools provided by Redux make it easier to understand when, where, why, and how the state in your application is being updated, and how your application logic will behave when those changes occur**<span offset-key="54d9d5bb321a4f58a4eaf2961f2ac859:1">. Redux guides you towards writing code that is predictable and testable, which helps give you confidence that your application will work as expected.</span></span>

### 

<span key="c660d4f97f7b4c8a9da0ff573cbf8b81"><span offset-key="c660d4f97f7b4c8a9da0ff573cbf8b81:0">When Should I Use Redux?</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#when-should-i-use-redux" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="067843f1e2884c02ace2f1080dd16839" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="6285944dc3fd49f7afbd1b1fb6cc7667"><span data-offset-key="6285944dc3fd49f7afbd1b1fb6cc7667:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="05d06de5a9a947739086e0bd2efc470f"><span offset-key="05d06de5a9a947739086e0bd2efc470f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="4618c93b84a140c4a3d4fbc1f8ea176d"><span offset-key="4618c93b84a140c4a3d4fbc1f8ea176d:0">Redux helps you deal with shared state management, but like any tool, it has tradeoffs. There are more concepts to learn, and more code to write. It also adds some indirection to your code, and asks you to follow certain restrictions. It's a trade-off between short term and long term productivity.</span></span>

<span key="0427e3018d644661a6c7ad29eeab66ea"><span offset-key="0427e3018d644661a6c7ad29eeab66ea:0">Redux is more useful when:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="e6d2af191da3431cbc91f366f12d0631"><span offset-key="e6d2af191da3431cbc91f366f12d0631:0">You have large amounts of application state that are needed in many places in the app</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="936d475f668448b98ae0e7351b2c9552"><span offset-key="936d475f668448b98ae0e7351b2c9552:0">The app state is updated frequently over time</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="db92391fdd8d43aa83afb6d959d77db3"><span offset-key="db92391fdd8d43aa83afb6d959d77db3:0">The logic to update that state may be complex</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="9efc6b16be124ee1965e60933bf31f62"><span offset-key="9efc6b16be124ee1965e60933bf31f62:0">The app has a medium or large-sized codebase, and might be worked on by many people</span></span>

<span key="603e9c4d9a714c4a9133d31c070c29d6">**Not all apps need Redux. Take some time to think about the kind of app you're building, and decide what tools would be best to help solve the problems you're working on.**</span>

### 

<span key="80a9552b50fb4cfaa0248400d7658323"><span offset-key="80a9552b50fb4cfaa0248400d7658323:0">Redux Libraries and Tools</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#redux-libraries-and-tools" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="9f9293cb3ea04117b5ba734b4c37ec15" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="9cfa228f50034e3fbc9c84b7c8d827dc"><span data-offset-key="9cfa228f50034e3fbc9c84b7c8d827dc:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="a44f5a2145ef4623bfd900e5201af5dc"><span offset-key="a44f5a2145ef4623bfd900e5201af5dc:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="ec110cdfac8f48669d26b72f92bdbbfe"><span offset-key="ec110cdfac8f48669d26b72f92bdbbfe:0">Redux is a small standalone JS library. However, it is commonly used with several other packages:</span></span>

<span key="907ef0dc59ba406e8fb9ac7d2115ca0d">**React-Redux#**</span>

<span key="74ced532891648ae96fc29ca4bf09f3c"><span offset-key="74ced532891648ae96fc29ca4bf09f3c:0">Redux can integrate with any UI framework, and is most frequently used with React. </span></span><a href="https://react-redux.js.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="87a9eecb2e21459b9316d020600bac31" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="aa5cec1445904d52b38caa4d2534523b"><strong>React-Redux</strong></span></span></a><span key="6b5cc222aa9c47ebb5adbc7d50efa9ee"><span offset-key="6b5cc222aa9c47ebb5adbc7d50efa9ee:0"> is our official package that lets your React components interact with a Redux store by reading pieces of state and dispatching actions to update the store.</span></span>

<span key="97bafa96945444d09e29678d7ec2b54a">**Redux Toolkit#**</span>

<span key="7fc883cb5a0f40eeb359ba669586da30"><span offset-key="7fc883cb5a0f40eeb359ba669586da30:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span><a href="https://redux-toolkit.js.org" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="ce09b74a7967443fa2735d8836922b9b" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="8c61c850e3fd42088675e157c142ac6a"><strong>Redux Toolkit</strong></span></span></a><span key="c96f7f987ca94e91b85c5c78316b6104"><span offset-key="c96f7f987ca94e91b85c5c78316b6104:0"> is our recommended approach for writing Redux logic. It contains packages and functions that we think are essential for building a Redux app. Redux Toolkit builds in our suggested best practices, simplifies most Redux tasks, prevents common mistakes, and makes it easier to write Redux applications.</span></span>

<span key="210827e559db4bf3ad1bc40845070a28">**Redux DevTools Extension#**</span>

<span key="507d657a52e840c2a0164da9e2562288"><span offset-key="507d657a52e840c2a0164da9e2562288:0">The </span></span><a href="https://github.com/zalmoxisus/redux-devtools-extension" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f2f62ac07b994ca497fa1c73e6881340" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="89d9c1641f3a4bd9ad1b2650fb62004d"><strong>Redux DevTools Extension</strong></span></span></a><span key="b41fe8f9421443ba972c94e1048d909a"><span offset-key="b41fe8f9421443ba972c94e1048d909a:0"> shows a history of the changes to the state in your Redux store over time. This allows you to debug your applications effectively, including using powerful techniques like "time-travel debugging".</span></span>

## 

<span key="66a31990e3b54175b283e84e9a4d5132"><span offset-key="66a31990e3b54175b283e84e9a4d5132:0">Redux Terms and Concepts</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#redux-terms-and-concepts" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="e71ae1efb09b4853b71787ef80b17818" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="02ed188d52cc493b831de471fb8bf827"><span data-offset-key="02ed188d52cc493b831de471fb8bf827:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="886220da264347e59ae5cb52c50ac8d2"><span offset-key="886220da264347e59ae5cb52c50ac8d2:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="bf25f8962e5745d38e87d29cbf53d081"><span offset-key="bf25f8962e5745d38e87d29cbf53d081:0">Before we dive into some actual code, let's talk about some of the terms and concepts you'll need to know to use Redux.</span></span>

### 

<span key="7874f988c06546169abe85d00962c888"><span offset-key="7874f988c06546169abe85d00962c888:0">State Management</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#state-management" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a6a50acb142040f5b671c1f17a3e047e" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="1ccdbd192a0f45bba160855d821614f0"><span data-offset-key="1ccdbd192a0f45bba160855d821614f0:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="3da4ed2ac79a40819f9aa175f0cdce91"><span offset-key="3da4ed2ac79a40819f9aa175f0cdce91:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="09cfebbcf96d424a8d79061d77581a5a"><span offset-key="09cfebbcf96d424a8d79061d77581a5a:0">Let's start by looking at a small React counter component. It tracks a number in component state, and increments the number when a button is clicked:</span></span>

<span key="a34eb2d2b6fb40509b1675431d876207"><span offset-key="a34eb2d2b6fb40509b1675431d876207:0">It is a self-contained app with the following parts:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="f247e1759df94b53b90c61c58c0ea149"><span offset-key="f247e1759df94b53b90c61c58c0ea149:0">The </span>**state**<span offset-key="f247e1759df94b53b90c61c58c0ea149:2">, the source of truth that drives our app;</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="ccde3b7825c3414ba67bff96f399efec"><span offset-key="ccde3b7825c3414ba67bff96f399efec:0">The </span>**view**<span offset-key="ccde3b7825c3414ba67bff96f399efec:2">, a declarative description of the UI based on the current state</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="b01907d8c1764556b597c3971ace9fff"><span offset-key="b01907d8c1764556b597c3971ace9fff:0">The </span>**actions**<span offset-key="b01907d8c1764556b597c3971ace9fff:2">, the events that occur in the app based on user input, and trigger updates in the state</span></span>

<span key="359907f56d1e47618927cb0e56ae65fa"><span offset-key="359907f56d1e47618927cb0e56ae65fa:0">This is a small example of </span>**"one-way data flow"**<span offset-key="359907f56d1e47618927cb0e56ae65fa:2">:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="d3e8f6f70537476fab97ee78c8c2ccfd"><span offset-key="d3e8f6f70537476fab97ee78c8c2ccfd:0">State describes the condition of the app at a specific point in time</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="99c7762bbd5a48b9b9af8d349f71dbd5"><span offset-key="99c7762bbd5a48b9b9af8d349f71dbd5:0">The UI is rendered based on that state</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="a2120c2c4c514a19a9e512f5f9cf7346"><span offset-key="a2120c2c4c514a19a9e512f5f9cf7346:0">When something happens (such as a user clicking a button), the state is updated based on what occurred</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="bf57e7489fe0464d857b9c5511125dde"><span offset-key="bf57e7489fe0464d857b9c5511125dde:0">The UI re-renders based on the new state</span></span>

<span key="58c29c9cf60e41c7917bb00530b4b0c5"><span offset-key="58c29c9cf60e41c7917bb00530b4b0c5:0">One-way data flow</span></span>

<span key="969795589b9c4ff8afc2129754eab2d0"><span offset-key="969795589b9c4ff8afc2129754eab2d0:0">However, the simplicity can break down when we have </span>**multiple components that need to share and use the same state**<span offset-key="969795589b9c4ff8afc2129754eab2d0:2">, especially if those components are located in different parts of the application. Sometimes this can be solved by </span></span><a href="https://reactjs.org/docs/lifting-state-up.html" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="68c33a16a9ea45f68ef1fb1fa678f607" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="9a8411f828df4557a40601d99a44a7d6"><span data-offset-key="9a8411f828df4557a40601d99a44a7d6:0">"lifting state up"</span></span></span></a><span key="f8685d295aaf4e63a13c56529ca699d9"><span offset-key="f8685d295aaf4e63a13c56529ca699d9:0"> to parent components, but that doesn't always help.</span></span>

<span key="5eee46cd17e946c8b089742cc7d593bf"><span offset-key="5eee46cd17e946c8b089742cc7d593bf:0">One way to solve this is to extract the shared state from the components, and put it into a centralized location outside the component tree. With this, our component tree becomes a big "view", and any component can access the state or trigger actions, no matter where they are in the tree!</span></span>

<span key="193a845c30354abf842118cddc4ab017"><span offset-key="193a845c30354abf842118cddc4ab017:0">By defining and separating the concepts involved in state management and enforcing rules that maintain independence between views and states, we give our code more structure and maintainability.</span></span>

<span key="73ea56e28730447cb969280166d5cb7d"><span offset-key="73ea56e28730447cb969280166d5cb7d:0">This is the basic idea behind Redux: a single centralized place to contain the global state in your application, and specific patterns to follow when updating that state to make the code predictable.</span></span>

### 

<span key="9433f1a114e54aeb96ed15344098fff3"><span offset-key="9433f1a114e54aeb96ed15344098fff3:0">Immutability</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#immutability" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="e21ac09c53c549cc87d641cc48aa8017" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="902b2b2ce68345709c51e724ec2001e9"><span data-offset-key="902b2b2ce68345709c51e724ec2001e9:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="34fc0314a4e44cc58ffb35fec3ca7538"><span offset-key="34fc0314a4e44cc58ffb35fec3ca7538:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="34140756852748a280a67e2501b8058f"><span offset-key="34140756852748a280a67e2501b8058f:0">"Mutable" means "changeable". If something is "immutable", it can never be changed.</span></span>

<span key="41c35771fb9b4b4f86f81b4cf83da857"><span offset-key="41c35771fb9b4b4f86f81b4cf83da857:0">JavaScript objects and arrays are all mutable by default. If I create an object, I can change the contents of its fields. If I create an array, I can change the contents as well:</span></span>

<span key="2ff3f31be14e4394b5e7ff202623fbcf"><span offset-key="2ff3f31be14e4394b5e7ff202623fbcf:0">This is called </span>*mutating*<span offset-key="2ff3f31be14e4394b5e7ff202623fbcf:2"> the object or array. It's the same object or array reference in memory, but now the contents inside the object have changed.</span></span>

<span key="f48f80eabcf34c5685a1f91a0ef7006b">**In order to update values immutably, your code must make** ***copies*** **of existing objects/arrays, and then modify the copies**<span offset-key="f48f80eabcf34c5685a1f91a0ef7006b:3">.</span></span>

<span key="ad43e29281624b669b421ca66b06794d"><span offset-key="ad43e29281624b669b421ca66b06794d:0">We can do this by hand using JavaScript's array / object spread operators, as well as array methods that return new copies of the array instead of mutating the original array:</span></span>

<span key="268053c80afd4c98b6916572f4138145">**Redux expects that all state updates are done immutably**<span offset-key="268053c80afd4c98b6916572f4138145:1">. We'll look at where and how this is important a bit later, as well as some easier ways to write immutable update logic.</span></span>

### 

<span key="1fe8aa5c8b9541438a1a0de35c670fe0"><span offset-key="1fe8aa5c8b9541438a1a0de35c670fe0:0">Terminology</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#terminology" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="fa9eeec37c0d43c6898556bd1234369a" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="8ad425ce449743ad940d4b68ae5d56a7"><span data-offset-key="8ad425ce449743ad940d4b68ae5d56a7:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="3e443d13e29945d794a07a421a0073c7"><span offset-key="3e443d13e29945d794a07a421a0073c7:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="adb223b30b2a483693add67c8cb3aba8"><span offset-key="adb223b30b2a483693add67c8cb3aba8:0">There are some important Redux terms that you'll need to be familiar with before we continue:</span></span>

<span key="c8c5eded67d8432eb5f4ce0267956a66">**Actions#**</span>

<span key="670f01dd37cd486d97e230d6d6d34455"><span offset-key="670f01dd37cd486d97e230d6d6d34455:0">An </span>**action**<span offset-key="670f01dd37cd486d97e230d6d6d34455:2"> is a plain JavaScript object that has a </span>`type`<span offset-key="670f01dd37cd486d97e230d6d6d34455:4"> field. </span>**You can think of an action as an event that describes something that happened in the application**<span offset-key="670f01dd37cd486d97e230d6d6d34455:6">.</span></span>

<span key="953e06c8138f41c9ae9cb8d2dc92f214"><span offset-key="953e06c8138f41c9ae9cb8d2dc92f214:0">The </span>`type`<span offset-key="953e06c8138f41c9ae9cb8d2dc92f214:2"> field should be a string that gives this action a descriptive name, like </span>`"todos/todoAdded"`<span offset-key="953e06c8138f41c9ae9cb8d2dc92f214:4">. We usually write that type string like </span>`"domain/eventName"`<span offset-key="953e06c8138f41c9ae9cb8d2dc92f214:6"> , where the first part is the feature or category that this action belongs to, and the second part is the specific thing that happened.</span></span>

<span key="efb718235c8245b0be21a2411cbcf628"><span offset-key="efb718235c8245b0be21a2411cbcf628:0">An action object can have other fields with additional information about what happened. By convention, we put that information in a field called </span>`payload`<span offset-key="efb718235c8245b0be21a2411cbcf628:2">.</span></span>

<span key="8f4db2e6b02a437a9fea2f0d0be2879b"><span offset-key="8f4db2e6b02a437a9fea2f0d0be2879b:0">A typical action object might look like this:</span></span>

<span key="4b27e166cf114b1b964086080337c5e8">**Action Creators#**</span>

<span key="bcd395cd85a34bf0853efbee9ba7e9c2"><span offset-key="bcd395cd85a34bf0853efbee9ba7e9c2:0">An </span>**action creator**<span offset-key="bcd395cd85a34bf0853efbee9ba7e9c2:2"> is a function that creates and returns an action object. We typically use these so we don't have to write the action object by hand every time:</span></span>

<span key="c5bb41a30ddb4adda591cbcd17a45c7b">**Reducers#**</span>

<span key="212ed8229bd7481eb110dfefe62cd998"><span offset-key="212ed8229bd7481eb110dfefe62cd998:0">A </span>**reducer**<span offset-key="212ed8229bd7481eb110dfefe62cd998:2"> is a function that receives the current </span>`state`<span offset-key="212ed8229bd7481eb110dfefe62cd998:4"> and an </span>`action`<span offset-key="212ed8229bd7481eb110dfefe62cd998:6"> object, decides how to update the state if necessary, and returns the new state: </span>`(state, action) => newState`<span offset-key="212ed8229bd7481eb110dfefe62cd998:8">. </span>**You can think of a reducer as an event listener which handles events based on the received action (event) type.**</span>

<span key="b2bf565221404eed8cf0494a35907515">**info**</span>

<span key="6873564673b84ef7a1aa1cc092ea4a70"><span offset-key="6873564673b84ef7a1aa1cc092ea4a70:0">"Reducer" functions get their name because they're similar to the kind of callback function you pass to the </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reduce" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="624636b54ed94d5fac8c8878b5217a18" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="3113ad904b9a4f80892c48cab0f2c24f"><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="3113ad904b9a4f80892c48cab0f2c24f:0">Array.reduce()</code></span></span></a><span key="79650298b52a449bbc6e66c266cd85a2"><span offset-key="79650298b52a449bbc6e66c266cd85a2:0"> method.</span></span>

<span key="f180caa952fb4c6dae455ff4061c217c"><span offset-key="f180caa952fb4c6dae455ff4061c217c:0">Reducers must </span>*always*<span offset-key="f180caa952fb4c6dae455ff4061c217c:2"> follow some specific rules:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="7dee110b6c3e4bec9a3f220b1972366c"><span offset-key="7dee110b6c3e4bec9a3f220b1972366c:0">They should only calculate the new state value based on the </span>`state`<span offset-key="7dee110b6c3e4bec9a3f220b1972366c:2"> and </span>`action`<span offset-key="7dee110b6c3e4bec9a3f220b1972366c:4"> arguments</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="1373d1c70a22456a9ccb940f741d2b44"><span offset-key="1373d1c70a22456a9ccb940f741d2b44:0">They are not allowed to modify the existing </span>`state`<span offset-key="1373d1c70a22456a9ccb940f741d2b44:2">. Instead, they must make </span>*immutable updates*<span offset-key="1373d1c70a22456a9ccb940f741d2b44:4">, by copying the existing </span>`state`<span offset-key="1373d1c70a22456a9ccb940f741d2b44:6"> and making changes to the copied values.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="b2ae1b5b91f148a5a4b273e510dec41a"><span offset-key="b2ae1b5b91f148a5a4b273e510dec41a:0">They must not do any asynchronous logic, calculate random values, or cause other "side effects"</span></span>

<span key="68220cd2f7384f1d8c98d5132ba4d04e"><span offset-key="68220cd2f7384f1d8c98d5132ba4d04e:0">We'll talk more about the rules of reducers later, including why they're important and how to follow them correctly.</span></span>

<span key="3a78697333ce4c1bb5078d7ec64a0bac"><span offset-key="3a78697333ce4c1bb5078d7ec64a0bac:0">The logic inside reducer functions typically follows the same series of steps:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="ff029d82a3f24ce18ed88a9ede0bfb4d"><span offset-key="ff029d82a3f24ce18ed88a9ede0bfb4d:0">Check to see if the reducer cares about this action</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="1626ed30571b4d888e21492e4f0a190b"><span offset-key="1626ed30571b4d888e21492e4f0a190b:0">If so, make a copy of the state, update the copy with new values, and return it</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="c077196be1c0490ab50cdd5ace672f89"><span offset-key="c077196be1c0490ab50cdd5ace672f89:0">Otherwise, return the existing state unchanged</span></span>

<span key="7d8a9c9f70cd4bc2a8163c1a0a3d73d5"><span offset-key="7d8a9c9f70cd4bc2a8163c1a0a3d73d5:0">Here's a small example of a reducer, showing the steps that each reducer should follow:</span></span>

<span key="071cd9ce86004ebfa73ce95fe949cc38"><span offset-key="071cd9ce86004ebfa73ce95fe949cc38:0">Reducers can use any kind of logic inside to decide what the new state should be: </span>`if/else`<span offset-key="071cd9ce86004ebfa73ce95fe949cc38:2">, </span>`switch`<span offset-key="071cd9ce86004ebfa73ce95fe949cc38:4">, loops, and so on.</span></span>

<span key="1f5f7248a1434c96a68ba2bd35326ada">**Detailed Explanation: Why Are They Called 'Reducers?'**</span>

<span key="1c1701b26dfc483683a31d7e775c0cd2"><span offset-key="1c1701b26dfc483683a31d7e775c0cd2:0">The </span></span><a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/reduce" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="54cbd4f3f9314d25968cf15d02522c95" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="74b163951e8f466590ac216a755f8a40"><code class="r-1vckr1u r-z2wwpe r-uibjmv r-m2pi6t r-1hvjb8t" data-slate-leaf="true" data-offset-key="74b163951e8f466590ac216a755f8a40:0">Array.reduce()</code></span></span></a><span key="d82bedc1e6904bf08cdb210b6d1d101d"><span offset-key="d82bedc1e6904bf08cdb210b6d1d101d:0"> method lets you take an array of values, process each item in the array one at a time, and return a single final result. You can think of it as "reducing the array down to one value".</span></span>

<span key="ac9b3ce063144c1bb7363f083f8e17d1">`Array.reduce()`<span offset-key="ac9b3ce063144c1bb7363f083f8e17d1:1"> takes a callback function as an argument, which will be called one time for each item in the array. It takes two arguments:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="ce69d5a337c94354bd47882464d06aea">`previousResult`<span offset-key="ce69d5a337c94354bd47882464d06aea:1">, the value that your callback returned last time</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="432ba8eabf47403ebb16d9277c6a4a2c">`currentItem`<span offset-key="432ba8eabf47403ebb16d9277c6a4a2c:1">, the current item in the array</span></span>

<span key="309502b9dbb54646b6cc44d779e40516"><span offset-key="309502b9dbb54646b6cc44d779e40516:0">The first time that the callback runs, there isn't a </span>`previousResult`<span offset-key="309502b9dbb54646b6cc44d779e40516:2"> available, so we need to also pass in an initial value that will be used as the first </span>`previousResult`<span offset-key="309502b9dbb54646b6cc44d779e40516:4">.</span></span>

<span key="ed4d403e63054ec581b9c489c4123f89"><span offset-key="ed4d403e63054ec581b9c489c4123f89:0">If we wanted to add together an array of numbers to find out what the total is, we could write a reduce callback that looks like this:</span></span>

<span key="670ec59e0a924d32905e07c0f6a3397f"><span offset-key="670ec59e0a924d32905e07c0f6a3397f:0">Notice that this </span>`addNumbers`<span offset-key="670ec59e0a924d32905e07c0f6a3397f:2"> "reduce callback" function doesn't need to keep track of anything itself. It takes the </span>`previousResult`<span offset-key="670ec59e0a924d32905e07c0f6a3397f:4"> and </span>`currentItem`<span offset-key="670ec59e0a924d32905e07c0f6a3397f:6"> arguments, does something with them, and returns a new result value.</span></span>

<span key="c700fc2d87fa453f945f100dca484ea8">**A Redux reducer function is exactly the same idea as this "reduce callback" function!**<span offset-key="c700fc2d87fa453f945f100dca484ea8:1"> It takes a "previous result" (the </span>`state`<span offset-key="c700fc2d87fa453f945f100dca484ea8:3">), and the "current item" (the </span>`action`<span offset-key="c700fc2d87fa453f945f100dca484ea8:5"> object), decides a new state value based on those arguments, and returns that new state.</span></span>

<span key="ac6a5b89b1a141d8a515b464287875e6"><span offset-key="ac6a5b89b1a141d8a515b464287875e6:0">If we were to create an array of Redux actions, call </span>`reduce()`<span offset-key="ac6a5b89b1a141d8a515b464287875e6:2">, and pass in a reducer function, we'd get a final result the same way:</span></span>

<span key="ef3d3df385f74b8992a69b3a249fc9d5"><span offset-key="ef3d3df385f74b8992a69b3a249fc9d5:0">We can say that </span>**Redux reducers reduce a set of actions (over time) into a single state**<span offset-key="ef3d3df385f74b8992a69b3a249fc9d5:2">. The difference is that with </span>`Array.reduce()`<span offset-key="ef3d3df385f74b8992a69b3a249fc9d5:4"> it happens all at once, and with Redux, it happens over the lifetime of your running app.</span></span>

<span key="10d18f090d524395a1ebb48359ea72c8">**Store#**</span>

<span key="83564e5f1c5b41e68abbf38dedf9d51a"><span offset-key="83564e5f1c5b41e68abbf38dedf9d51a:0">The current Redux application state lives in an object called the </span>**store**<span offset-key="83564e5f1c5b41e68abbf38dedf9d51a:2"> .</span></span>

<span key="739149db19934509adaca8bc859c62e4"><span offset-key="739149db19934509adaca8bc859c62e4:0">The store is created by passing in a reducer, and has a method called </span>`getState`<span offset-key="739149db19934509adaca8bc859c62e4:2"> that returns the current state value:</span></span>

<span key="0df28a9eca1644e0918fcce231b38df7">**Dispatch#**</span>

<span key="98c359d074aa48e4baee6e08ce18ce49"><span offset-key="98c359d074aa48e4baee6e08ce18ce49:0">The Redux store has a method called </span>`dispatch`<span offset-key="98c359d074aa48e4baee6e08ce18ce49:2">. </span>**The only way to update the state is to call** **`store.dispatch()`** **and pass in an action object**<span offset-key="98c359d074aa48e4baee6e08ce18ce49:6">. The store will run its reducer function and save the new state value inside, and we can call </span>`getState()`<span offset-key="98c359d074aa48e4baee6e08ce18ce49:8"> to retrieve the updated value:</span></span>

<span key="08c08d1e058c4115b1fc69833184a8a4">**You can think of dispatching actions as "triggering an event"**<span offset-key="08c08d1e058c4115b1fc69833184a8a4:1"> in the application. Something happened, and we want the store to know about it. Reducers act like event listeners, and when they hear an action they are interested in, they update the state in response.</span></span>

<span key="cd7afc88d08a45c7833bdc3dcfa5c2b3"><span offset-key="cd7afc88d08a45c7833bdc3dcfa5c2b3:0">We typically call action creators to dispatch the right action:</span></span>

<span key="3eba07e64c334ec2ae67e4bda21d7f3b">**Selectors#**</span>

<span key="de10eb85aed44989b22144ea11273aa0">**Selectors**<span offset-key="de10eb85aed44989b22144ea11273aa0:1"> are functions that know how to extract specific pieces of information from a store state value. As an application grows bigger, this can help avoid repeating logic as different parts of the app need to read the same data:</span></span>

### 

<span key="954923cf6b964d47a152762bb46536b3"><span offset-key="954923cf6b964d47a152762bb46536b3:0">Redux Application Data Flow</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#redux-application-data-flow" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="6de308198cf145d68328c359d14b8066" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="3f045d37cab34a62959715064c3c4e83"><span data-offset-key="3f045d37cab34a62959715064c3c4e83:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="7ab506db4ea34505891bb80aa47aa7ef"><span offset-key="7ab506db4ea34505891bb80aa47aa7ef:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="289d98677a054af1b82dfc36b24c3a87"><span offset-key="289d98677a054af1b82dfc36b24c3a87:0">Earlier, we talked about "one-way data flow", which describes this sequence of steps to update the app:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="1fac3855462a4df1a2b81e6316ae12ce"><span offset-key="1fac3855462a4df1a2b81e6316ae12ce:0">State describes the condition of the app at a specific point in time</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="753d4e780d2f43808896c8f4d5b7914e"><span offset-key="753d4e780d2f43808896c8f4d5b7914e:0">The UI is rendered based on that state</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="8a38e6c4b38d418a92b5b043ae89d6ee"><span offset-key="8a38e6c4b38d418a92b5b043ae89d6ee:0">When something happens (such as a user clicking a button), the state is updated based on what occurred</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="bebe8c87ccf8490d9fb5c3ae40777437"><span offset-key="bebe8c87ccf8490d9fb5c3ae40777437:0">The UI re-renders based on the new state</span></span>

<span key="9390162e0198439491f53fa2f1207fd4"><span offset-key="9390162e0198439491f53fa2f1207fd4:0">For Redux specifically, we can break these steps into more detail:</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="9c2b16e4420747cc9d000b42ebb752be"><span offset-key="9c2b16e4420747cc9d000b42ebb752be:0">Initial setup:</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="d880efd915944403bf372800a8717483"><span offset-key="d880efd915944403bf372800a8717483:0">A Redux store is created using a root reducer function</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="b8a08b2439ff442cae3f38b9ce845cb7"><span offset-key="b8a08b2439ff442cae3f38b9ce845cb7:0">The store calls the root reducer once, and saves the return value as its initial </span>`state`</span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="14ca3ef53b3c4a3d86e6ad9cecc61fda"><span offset-key="14ca3ef53b3c4a3d86e6ad9cecc61fda:0">When the UI is first rendered, UI components access the current state of the Redux store, and use that data to decide what to render. They also subscribe to any future store updates so they can know if the state has changed.</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="6c3af3f7eb214c56882aae8233cc462a"><span offset-key="6c3af3f7eb214c56882aae8233cc462a:0">Updates:</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="b61ce3f8e9f04fce92aee91b531a93ec"><span offset-key="b61ce3f8e9f04fce92aee91b531a93ec:0">Something happens in the app, such as a user clicking a button</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="0023243cfb514460ac75678b066e4587"><span offset-key="0023243cfb514460ac75678b066e4587:0">The app code dispatches an action to the Redux store, like </span>`dispatch({type: 'counter/increment'})`</span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="933f716ac8764ffcbeb546f3ea301483"><span offset-key="933f716ac8764ffcbeb546f3ea301483:0">The store runs the reducer function again with the previous </span>`state`<span offset-key="933f716ac8764ffcbeb546f3ea301483:2"> and the current </span>`action`<span offset-key="933f716ac8764ffcbeb546f3ea301483:4">, and saves the return value as the new </span>`state`</span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="b3359b7db3e24ce5b4954237da966199"><span offset-key="b3359b7db3e24ce5b4954237da966199:0">The store notifies all parts of the UI that are subscribed that the store has been updated</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="0f2f806b767149c1966f5c9ccbf01c72"><span offset-key="0f2f806b767149c1966f5c9ccbf01c72:0">Each UI component that needs data from the store checks to see if the parts of the state they need have changed.</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="d81f6918b92646ddb0e7d1afdc5b43ef"><span offset-key="d81f6918b92646ddb0e7d1afdc5b43ef:0">Each component that sees its data has changed forces a re-render with the new data, so it can update what's shown on the screen</span></span>

<span key="38c9ce94c036426780ef970356c1a3bf"><span offset-key="38c9ce94c036426780ef970356c1a3bf:0">Here's what that data flow looks like visually:</span></span>

<span key="6a7e3fa38e7547fbb48513647ca2dd88"><span offset-key="6a7e3fa38e7547fbb48513647ca2dd88:0">Redux data flow diagram</span></span>

## 

<span key="3716087ed86c432898a8fb8c8d3bdd01"><span offset-key="3716087ed86c432898a8fb8c8d3bdd01:0">What You've Learned</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#what-youve-learned" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="4bbd5a79be53474ebec09888ab6d9197" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="db6a938bf5e64542b3cc9174b4c74b14"><span data-offset-key="db6a938bf5e64542b3cc9174b4c74b14:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="223adbdebcc04e438dc3a529f5635906"><span offset-key="223adbdebcc04e438dc3a529f5635906:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="3a46c71888a648a7ac8e6d24e56af0eb"><span offset-key="3a46c71888a648a7ac8e6d24e56af0eb:0">Redux does have a number of new terms and concepts to remember. As a reminder, here's what we just covered:</span></span>

<span key="9c1ae7cbbea247198be4c156f4d19a6b">**Summary**</span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="52902756c7c74fc490abe56ad6dc9fec">**Redux is a library for managing global application state**</span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="e0766a3354fa4ffab9e8c99daf0974c9"><span offset-key="e0766a3354fa4ffab9e8c99daf0974c9:0">Redux is typically used with the React-Redux library for integrating Redux and React together</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="fb08968326e64c558e52c6c9d2d98908"><span offset-key="fb08968326e64c558e52c6c9d2d98908:0">Redux Toolkit is the recommended way to write Redux logic</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="1ebacb8f34464a3380ddaabcbb7cd1af">**Redux uses a "one-way data flow" app structure**</span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="21b451bde7e34e2f80d389b6ecb89e0a"><span offset-key="21b451bde7e34e2f80d389b6ecb89e0a:0">State describes the condition of the app at a point in time, and UI renders based on that state</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="bc77d23e3f384e019f647f39619ae2c8"><span offset-key="bc77d23e3f384e019f647f39619ae2c8:0">When something happens in the app:</span></span>

        -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

            <span key="ab7f7a81629e45c18a9c56641d5195da"><span offset-key="ab7f7a81629e45c18a9c56641d5195da:0">The UI dispatches an action</span></span>

        -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

            <span key="a9096a04ba954dd4a6d6e1efb4fccadb"><span offset-key="a9096a04ba954dd4a6d6e1efb4fccadb:0">The store runs the reducers, and the state is updated based on what occurred</span></span>

        -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

            <span key="a933d81b4e3141bd821a96e06a804fdc"><span offset-key="a933d81b4e3141bd821a96e06a804fdc:0">The store notifies the UI that the state has changed</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="461eb66442c24f0fbd9c4384517587c9"><span offset-key="461eb66442c24f0fbd9c4384517587c9:0">The UI re-renders based on the new state</span></span>

-   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

    <span key="4f18985552c6428aa70628be0ad44a92">**Redux uses several types of code**</span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="829911707a25461f881c8f7cc8dadb29">*Actions*<span offset-key="829911707a25461f881c8f7cc8dadb29:1"> are plain objects with a </span>`type`<span offset-key="829911707a25461f881c8f7cc8dadb29:3"> field, and describe "what happened" in the app</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="a1f66a70b6b94473a831fd4e60ded74c">*Reducers*<span offset-key="a1f66a70b6b94473a831fd4e60ded74c:1"> are functions that calculate a new state value based on previous state + an action</span></span>

    -   <img src="data:image/svg+xml;base64," class="r-1nf4jbm" />

        <span key="ada66d74f165494f97a395e7a42fc5ac"><span offset-key="ada66d74f165494f97a395e7a42fc5ac:0">A Redux </span>*store*<span offset-key="ada66d74f165494f97a395e7a42fc5ac:2"> runs the root reducer whenever an action is </span>*dispatched*</span>

## 

<span key="0609899f43f34a81ae21918140c79b20"><span offset-key="0609899f43f34a81ae21918140c79b20:0">What's Next?</span></span><a href="https://learning-redux42.netlify.app/#whats-next" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="8d83a4e15b564232b76eec03309b8f06" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="ce4ad273413a4b889ff46335e9a06918"><span data-offset-key="ce4ad273413a4b889ff46335e9a06918:0">#</span></span></span></a><span key="a79b89b1df3f4c7ba71c5384129d9c42"><span offset-key="a79b89b1df3f4c7ba71c5384129d9c42:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

<span key="e204f88b5c324c8b8e87c5b831f0ced3"><span offset-key="e204f88b5c324c8b8e87c5b831f0ced3:0">We've seen each of the individual pieces of a Redux app. Next, continue on to </span></span><a href="https://chrome-extension/cjedbglnccaioiolemnfhjncicchinao/tutorials/essentials/part-2-app-structure" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="f90729136b134d40814d8bf812d074a1" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="7746cd9ce31b41a9bf0551592575a3d4"><span data-offset-key="7746cd9ce31b41a9bf0551592575a3d4:0">Part 2: Redux App Structure</span></span></span></a><span key="a323b2969d7e44aab03e70b535747a24"><span offset-key="a323b2969d7e44aab03e70b535747a24:0">, where we'll look at a full working example to see how the pieces fit together.</span></span>

## 

<span key="6a375c0ea2194b93bf6c0894dbff5a1e"><span offset-key="6a375c0ea2194b93bf6c0894dbff5a1e:0">When to use Redux</span></span>

<span key="9d8491ab9d5c404094a3458adae7c997"><span offset-key="9d8491ab9d5c404094a3458adae7c997:0">Lately one of the biggest debates in the frontend world has been about Redux. Not long after its release, Redux became one of the hottest topics of discussion. Many favored it while others pointed out issues.</span></span>

<span key="6b00931ba2ae4a9ba964ae80596a24eb"><span offset-key="6b00931ba2ae4a9ba964ae80596a24eb:0">Redux allows you to manage your appâ€™s state in a single place and keep changes in your app more predictable and traceable. It makes it easier to reason about changes occurring in your app. But all of these benefits come with tradeoffs and constraints. One might feel it adds up boilerplate code, making simple things a little overwhelming; but that depends upon the architecture decisions.</span></span>

<span key="1d696722cb084bf2a8ceb123de01dfec"><span offset-key="1d696722cb084bf2a8ceb123de01dfec:0">One simple answer to this question is you will realize for yourself when you need Redux. If youâ€™re still confused as to whether you need it, you donâ€™t. This usually happens when your app grows to the scale where managing app state becomes a hassle; and you start looking out for making it easy and simple.</span></span>

## 

<span key="32af5da3118f42a0a41bb24c6d174c69"><span offset-key="32af5da3118f42a0a41bb24c6d174c69:0">What is state management in Redux?</span></span>

<span key="ebb18cd1f4234f458ae2db7cee999a95"><span offset-key="ebb18cd1f4234f458ae2db7cee999a95:0">State management is essentially a way to facilitate communication and sharing of data across components. It creates a tangible data structure to represent the state of your app that you can read from and write to. That way, you can see otherwise invisible states while youâ€™re working with them.</span></span>

<span key="30deeb7683ea4ae9abe13a831edf3921"><span offset-key="30deeb7683ea4ae9abe13a831edf3921:0">Most libraries, such as React, Angular, etc. are built with a way for components to internally manage their state without any need for an external library or tool. It does well for applications with few components, but as the application grows bigger, managing states shared across components becomes a chore.</span></span>

<span key="16e0d2de6e3f4661b93c7c5bc772d063"><span offset-key="16e0d2de6e3f4661b93c7c5bc772d063:0">In an app where data is shared among components, it might be confusing to actually know where a state should live. Ideally, the data in a component should live in just one component, so sharing data among sibling components becomes difficult.</span></span>

<span key="b839d0c9b7294cbc8cba80e4d6c21fc7"><span offset-key="b839d0c9b7294cbc8cba80e4d6c21fc7:0">For instance, in React, to share data among siblings, a state has to live in the parent component. A method for updating this state is provided by the parent component and passed as props to these sibling components.</span></span>

<span key="3230b735021d45ae9e3efd1e9824ee23"><span offset-key="3230b735021d45ae9e3efd1e9824ee23:0">Hereâ€™s a simple example of a login component in React. The input of the login component affects what is displayed by its sibling component, the status component:</span></span>

1

<span key="c37d563b47af4813b41a54c29d284fa1"><span offset-key="c37d563b47af4813b41a54c29d284fa1:0"> class App extends React.Component {</span></span>

2

<span key="9b005dca16e849418d28f6078cf6e44e"><span offset-key="9b005dca16e849418d28f6078cf6e44e:0"> constructor(props) {</span></span>

3

<span key="fa2ca1338cb642868e9a56a895b656b7"><span offset-key="fa2ca1338cb642868e9a56a895b656b7:0"> super(props);</span></span>

4

<span key="f639b17b62bc4db3bf3054bbe9071167"><span offset-key="f639b17b62bc4db3bf3054bbe9071167:0"> this.state = { userStatus: "NOT LOGGED IN" };</span></span>

5

<span key="0e10b6c621c54a6da621899a4b2c5995"><span offset-key="0e10b6c621c54a6da621899a4b2c5995:0"> this.setStatus = this.setStatus.bind(this);</span></span>

6

<span key="9e761c027d0c4f08855f184ec0d304f7"><span offset-key="9e761c027d0c4f08855f184ec0d304f7:0"> }</span></span>

7

<span key="2ee02af82bb9458f95fc4016b2345e15"><span offset-key="2ee02af82bb9458f95fc4016b2345e15:0"> setStatus(username, password) {</span></span>

<span key="3269f0af541247478510fc7f8e373940"><span offset-key="3269f0af541247478510fc7f8e373940:0"> if (user.username == username && user.password === password) {</span></span>

Copied!

<span key="07287dcf7ca24a13b594d223adf53750"><span offset-key="07287dcf7ca24a13b594d223adf53750:0">&gt;</span></span>

> <span key="d80586a5f0194b6f930e6bf734d37906"><span offset-key="d80586a5f0194b6f930e6bf734d37906:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span><span slate-void="true" key="97da803e8dc94e1088dc2ebe01221bcc"></span>
>
> <span key="63867d73093e42908f1d408b89aa20b1"><span offset-key="63867d73093e42908f1d408b89aa20b1:0">Remember, this data is not needed by the parent component, but because its children need to share data, it has to provide a state.</span></span>

<span key="6fee2ddfff1c43d29f265d806f5793bd"><span offset-key="6fee2ddfff1c43d29f265d806f5793bd:0">Now imagine what happens when a state has to be shared between components that are far apart in the component tree. The state has to be passed from one component to another until it gets to where it is needed.</span></span>

<span key="8707556105744fc896532bb0d23d75b6"><span offset-key="8707556105744fc896532bb0d23d75b6:0">Basically, the state will have to be lifted up to the nearest parent component and to the next until it gets to an ancestor that is common to both components that need the state, and then it is passed down. This makes the state difficult to maintain and less predictable. It also means passing data to components that do not need it.</span></span>

<span key="bab93bd256f046cb9766dfa57ae16aac"><span offset-key="bab93bd256f046cb9766dfa57ae16aac:0">Itâ€™s clear that state management gets messy as the app gets complex. This is why you need a state management tool like Redux that makes it easier to maintain these states. Letâ€™s get a good overview of Redux concepts before considering its benefits.</span></span>

## 

<span key="4bff44cad67e4cd59b7dc3e19c963940"><span offset-key="4bff44cad67e4cd59b7dc3e19c963940:0">How Redux works</span></span>

<span key="fa2aa7bab4be49b0a15556b8e71a0de3"><span offset-key="fa2aa7bab4be49b0a15556b8e71a0de3:0">The way Redux works is simple. There is a central store that holds the entire state of the application. Each component can access the stored state without having to send down props from one component to another.</span></span>

<span key="41c91b2e4abc43d886186b95107eef1e"><span offset-key="41c91b2e4abc43d886186b95107eef1e:0">There are three building parts: actions, store, and reducers. Letâ€™s briefly discuss what each of them does. This is important because they help you understand the benefits of Redux and how itâ€™s to be used. Weâ€™ll be implementing a similar example to the login component above but this time in Redux.</span></span>

### 

<span key="0dfe1d77788d4ab7b483e2d26cf20959"><span offset-key="0dfe1d77788d4ab7b483e2d26cf20959:0">Actions in Redux</span></span>

<span key="e461281407b1477a840073932eca58da"><span offset-key="e461281407b1477a840073932eca58da:0">Simply put, actions are events. They are the only way you can send data from your application to your Redux store. The data can be from user interactions, API calls, or even form submissions.</span></span>

<span key="78b1374a1ce1487593684685b632cc18"><span offset-key="78b1374a1ce1487593684685b632cc18:0">Actions are sent using the </span>`store.dispatch()`<span offset-key="78b1374a1ce1487593684685b632cc18:2"> method. Actions are plain JavaScript objects, and they must have a type property to indicate the type of action to be carried out. They must also have a payload that contains the information that should be worked on by the action. Actions are created via an action creator.</span></span>

<span key="b5de7e414ea24b1b9be2a1e050b494b6"><span offset-key="b5de7e414ea24b1b9be2a1e050b494b6:0">Hereâ€™s an example of an action that can be carried out during login in an app:</span></span>

<span key="bb58479bca0c4e8fb5bc35259f94939c"><span offset-key="bb58479bca0c4e8fb5bc35259f94939c:0">{ type: "LOGIN", payload: { username: "foo", password: "bar" } }</span></span>

<span key="285390191bb041dcb30f1754ffa6c7af"><span offset-key="285390191bb041dcb30f1754ffa6c7af:0">Here is an example of its action creator:</span></span>

<span key="092cfd99ffbc491caac3768bec971682"><span offset-key="092cfd99ffbc491caac3768bec971682:0">const setLoginStatus = (name, password) => { return { type: "LOGIN", payload: { username: "foo", password: "bar" } } }</span></span>

<span key="e0bf7f9c028b41238c2b25a2ad013dda"><span offset-key="e0bf7f9c028b41238c2b25a2ad013dda:0">As explained earlier, the action must contain the type property and then the other payload to be stored.</span></span>

### 

<span key="4759311154534e428fdaa3def05542b0"><span offset-key="4759311154534e428fdaa3def05542b0:0">Reducers in Redux</span></span>

<span key="a50f1dcbef934833bf2cbea2a0ca035a"><span offset-key="a50f1dcbef934833bf2cbea2a0ca035a:0">Reducers are pure functions that take the current state of an application, perform an action, and return a new state. These states are stored as objects, and they specify how the state of an application changes in response to an action sent to the store.</span></span>

<span key="3adae86ccd9a4efd97fa891320793b14"><span offset-key="3adae86ccd9a4efd97fa891320793b14:0">It is based on the </span>`reduce`<span offset-key="3adae86ccd9a4efd97fa891320793b14:2"> function in JavaScript, where a single value is calculated from multiple values after a callback function has been carried out.</span></span>

<span key="f2fdb7012f6e41b6b422993f04a97cde"><span offset-key="f2fdb7012f6e41b6b422993f04a97cde:0">Here is an example of how reducers work in Redux:</span></span>

<span key="c2c218f3cbdc46deb1a6ffd1f23f2451"><span offset-key="c2c218f3cbdc46deb1a6ffd1f23f2451:0">const LoginComponent = (state = initialState, action) => { switch (action.type) { case "LOGIN": return state.map(user => { if (user.username !== action.username) { return user; } if (user.password == action.password) { return { ...user, login\_status: "LOGGED IN" } } }); default: return state; } };</span></span>

> <span key="b18ffc0dd76049918db0865c05b1a79d"><span offset-key="b18ffc0dd76049918db0865c05b1a79d:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span><span slate-void="true" key="78a94013ace94d1297634645cf59c8d8"></span>
>
> <span key="93c3c699a4204077b7b3c5dc484207a4"><span offset-key="93c3c699a4204077b7b3c5dc484207a4:0">Reducers take the previous state of the app and return a new state based on the action passed to it.</span></span>

<span key="907fa0e45a5e4db8a5141cb914bd8268"><span offset-key="907fa0e45a5e4db8a5141cb914bd8268:0">As pure functions, they do not change the data in the object passed to them or perform any side effect in the application. Given the same object, they should always produce the same result.</span></span>

### 

<span key="4af53ce130ee455095e8724040681a93"><span offset-key="4af53ce130ee455095e8724040681a93:0">Store in Redux</span></span>

<span key="a30b114d6b1740e78c08309ab18673c9"><span offset-key="a30b114d6b1740e78c08309ab18673c9:0">The store holds the application state. It is highly recommended to keep only one store in any Redux application. You can access the state stored, update the state, and register or unregister listeners via helper methods.</span></span>

<span key="1e8bfea0b0f6417ca71848b0160bdb02"><span offset-key="1e8bfea0b0f6417ca71848b0160bdb02:0">Letâ€™s create a store for our login app:</span></span>

<span key="f5ebf07cc81d4fceb488f87962d96378"><span offset-key="f5ebf07cc81d4fceb488f87962d96378:0">const store = createStore(LoginComponent);</span></span>

<span key="2e76347b39b9493b934a60aff2a21ddb"><span offset-key="2e76347b39b9493b934a60aff2a21ddb:0">Actions performed on the state always return a new state. Thus, the state is very easy and predictable.</span></span>

<span key="6c6e2465939d4744874e03b4886a39f3"><span offset-key="6c6e2465939d4744874e03b4886a39f3:0">Now that we know a little more about Redux, letâ€™s go back to our login component example that was implemented earlier and see how Redux can improve the component.</span></span>

<span key="68239dba94d64a6abff7ae11d164d2b2"><span offset-key="68239dba94d64a6abff7ae11d164d2b2:0">class App extends React.Component { render() { return (&lt;Status user={</span></span><a href="http://this.props.user.name" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="867e39a83b2a4d58912f894374b9597d" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="a90ef931eb08447d99e32839da95c87c"><span data-offset-key="a90ef931eb08447d99e32839da95c87c:0">this.props.user.name</span></span></span></a><span key="b34948607c514a31b5f21e6f4adaa9bc"><span offset-key="b34948607c514a31b5f21e6f4adaa9bc:0">}/> &lt;Login login={this.props.setLoginStatus}/> &lt;/div> ) } }</span></span>

<span key="8d5e71dfef5f4a68a15269d15846ade6"><span offset-key="8d5e71dfef5f4a68a15269d15846ade6:0">With Redux, thereâ€™s one general state in the store, and each component has access to the state. This eliminates the need to continuously pass state from one component to another. You can also select the slice from the store for a particular component; this makes your app more optimized.</span></span>

## 

<span key="efcd5536e04e47fe980f0f437015bd28"><span offset-key="efcd5536e04e47fe980f0f437015bd28:0">Redux middleware</span></span>

<span key="361b1e4d76b444a4a2f57f29a0fa540f"><span offset-key="361b1e4d76b444a4a2f57f29a0fa540f:0">Redux allows developers to intercept all actions dispatched from components before they are passed to the reducer function. This interception is done via middlewares.</span></span>

<span key="b0136c612d38483487da0bcd49b0d291"><span offset-key="b0136c612d38483487da0bcd49b0d291:0">Building on the example Login component discussed in the last section, we might want to sanitize the userâ€™s input before it reaches our store for further processing. This can be achieved via </span></span><a href="https://redux.js.org/understanding/history-and-design/middleware" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="a27743a777a640479415e20c66049fdb" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="d47000f1480d4b2f923fed2ec37c0f31"><span data-offset-key="d47000f1480d4b2f923fed2ec37c0f31:0">Redux middleware</span></span></span></a><span key="bb5a8fbbe17d4594b32342a62808ad4f"><span offset-key="bb5a8fbbe17d4594b32342a62808ad4f:0">.</span></span>

<span key="86edbedaa93b4547a42c00ca6aab288c"><span offset-key="86edbedaa93b4547a42c00ca6aab288c:0">Technically, middlewares are functions that call the next method received in an argument after processing the current action. These are called after every dispatch.</span></span>

<span key="29e88014aad947ce9d1b59b6a0cbd052"><span offset-key="29e88014aad947ce9d1b59b6a0cbd052:0">Hereâ€™s what a simple middleware looks like:</span></span>

<span key="79a0b45262134ce29f5caf88c220f7d8"><span offset-key="79a0b45262134ce29f5caf88c220f7d8:0">function simpleMiddleware({ getState, dispatch }) { return function(next){ return function(action){ const nextAction = next(action); const state = getState(); return nextAction; } } }</span></span>

<span key="c8eda8a48eb34733890a50759b38c19e"><span offset-key="c8eda8a48eb34733890a50759b38c19e:0">This might look a little overwhelming, but in most cases, you might not need to create your own middleware since the huge Redux community has already made a number of them available. If you feel middleware is required, you will enjoy it because it gives you a lot of power to do tons of great work with the best abstraction.</span></span>

## 

<span key="a1a46d1b1c044fadb5845840cc13cad2"><span offset-key="a1a46d1b1c044fadb5845840cc13cad2:0">Why use Redux?</span></span>

<span key="d95fc057f28149579af7cffc82aa1599"><span offset-key="d95fc057f28149579af7cffc82aa1599:0">When using Redux with React, states will no longer need to be lifted up. This makes it easier for you to trace which action causes any change.</span></span>

<span key="1b3cc044feda4efc813e7a27601c9e6e"><span offset-key="1b3cc044feda4efc813e7a27601c9e6e:0">As you can see in the example above, the component does not need to provide any state or method for its children components to share data among themselves. Everything is handled by Redux. This greatly simplifies the app and makes it easier to maintain.</span></span>

<span key="48f4cc4875f349c6bc530dfde126e474"><span offset-key="48f4cc4875f349c6bc530dfde126e474:0">This is the primary reason why you should use Redux, but itâ€™s not the only benefit. Take a look at the list below for a summary of what you stand to gain by using Redux for state management.</span></span>

### 

<span key="fb6698c404e545d985eac1518cda2974"><span offset-key="fb6698c404e545d985eac1518cda2974:0">Redux makes the state predictable</span></span>

<span key="ad2c1da85f544ce38145f9772f47ac7a"><span offset-key="ad2c1da85f544ce38145f9772f47ac7a:0">In Redux, the state is always predictable. If the same state and action are passed to a reducer, the same result is always produced because reducers are pure functions. The state is also immutable and is never changed. This makes it possible to implement arduous tasks like infinite undo and redo. It is also possible to implement time travel â€” that is, the ability to move back and forth among the previous states and view the results in real time.</span></span>

### 

<span key="9d4ed80805584b1d8f615235f653bb4c"><span offset-key="9d4ed80805584b1d8f615235f653bb4c:0">Redux is maintainable</span></span>

<span key="dfb0d7d8c68941bf919746b91910db9a"><span offset-key="dfb0d7d8c68941bf919746b91910db9a:0">Redux is strict about how code should be organized, which makes it easier for someone with knowledge of Redux to understand the structure of any Redux application. This generally makes it easier to maintain. This also helps you segregate your business logic from your component tree. For large scale apps, itâ€™s critical to </span></span><a href="https://buttercms.com/blog/react-best-practices-maintaining-large-scale-projects" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="00476d17a6b740219645f718c7d06fcc" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="3daa602f5e9e49df893bb5df66d2e2e1"><span data-offset-key="3daa602f5e9e49df893bb5df66d2e2e1:0">keep your app more predictable and maintainable.</span></span></span></a><span key="31016831de7546c59e7e3ade6f780b9f"><span offset-key="31016831de7546c59e7e3ade6f780b9f:0"><span slate-zero-width="z">â€‹</span></span></span>

### 

<span key="b507e66ee57344c68021c2637812ca13"><span offset-key="b507e66ee57344c68021c2637812ca13:0">Debugging is easy in Redux</span></span>

<span key="653ea412401a4b0b94dd6f73d283dd47"><span offset-key="653ea412401a4b0b94dd6f73d283dd47:0">Redux makes it easy to debug an application. By logging actions and state, it is easy to understand coding errors, network errors, and other forms of bugs that might come up during production.</span></span>

<span key="8f25906a6c6249d79b7ff6c2fd60214c"><span offset-key="8f25906a6c6249d79b7ff6c2fd60214c:0">Besides logging, it has </span></span><a href="https://blog.logrocket.com/redux-devtools-tips-tricks-for-faster-debugging/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="3b6ae5b1370b4bf789c15506a43228a0" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="f1a17e485dcc46cb86300891bc336a32"><span data-offset-key="f1a17e485dcc46cb86300891bc336a32:0">great DevTools that allow you to time-travel actions</span></span></span></a><span key="f09f7c10c5bf40aa9731a8737865f609"><span offset-key="f09f7c10c5bf40aa9731a8737865f609:0">, persist actions on page refresh, etc. For medium- and large-scale apps, debugging takes more time then actually developing features. Redux DevTools makes it easy to taker advantage of all Redux has to offer.</span></span>

### 

<span key="e8301271ba1a4ff69a0a9003d4f1fe11">**Performance Benefits**</span>

<span key="29042a6243f54bff8770a8c958e3eec2"><span offset-key="29042a6243f54bff8770a8c958e3eec2:0">You might assume that keeping the appâ€™s state global would result in some performance degradation. To a large extent, thatâ€™s not the case.</span></span>

<span key="9373ef691b3048d2b4a26c27030a52e7"><span offset-key="9373ef691b3048d2b4a26c27030a52e7:0">React Redux implements many performance optimizations internally so that your own connected component only rerenders when it actually needs to.</span></span>

### 

<span key="c06907b4bb0d48bf8337bce208d3ff87"><span offset-key="c06907b4bb0d48bf8337bce208d3ff87:0">Ease of testing</span></span>

<span key="56663dce16804181b49a8b0c88fb49c2"><span offset-key="56663dce16804181b49a8b0c88fb49c2:0">It is easy to test Redux apps since functions used to change the state of pure functions.</span></span>

### 

<span key="8b46524a462245dd89f7f4cbb10062c8"><span offset-key="8b46524a462245dd89f7f4cbb10062c8:0">State persistence</span></span>

<span key="c3b30f906a684bd1bf906a154c2ad0b2"><span offset-key="c3b30f906a684bd1bf906a154c2ad0b2:0">You can persist some of the appâ€™s state to local storage and restore it after a refresh. This can be really nifty.</span></span>

### 

<span key="598fef2b0c81451292127352963ad392"><span offset-key="598fef2b0c81451292127352963ad392:0">Server-side rendering</span></span>

<span key="794ee14bf5ae4c35b499997cbd0d0b19"><span offset-key="794ee14bf5ae4c35b499997cbd0d0b19:0">Redux can also be used for server-side rendering. With it, you can handle the initial render of the app by sending the state of an app to the server along with its response to the server request. The required components are then rendered in HTML and sent to the clients.</span></span>

<span key="0846736bfac3438f962feae540fcb26a"><span offset-key="0846736bfac3438f962feae540fcb26a:0">The LogRocket Redux middleware package adds an extra layer of visibility into your user sessions. LogRocket logs all actions and state from your Redux stores.</span></span>

## 

<span key="b06403f5057f48f8ad44c236d22d5829"><span offset-key="b06403f5057f48f8ad44c236d22d5829:0">Conclusion</span></span>

<span key="b6acdcdfa7b84d7786730ced76352a0e"><span offset-key="b6acdcdfa7b84d7786730ced76352a0e:0">We have discussed the major features of Redux and why Redux is beneficial to your app. While Redux has its benefits, that does not mean you should go about adding Redux in all of your apps. Your application </span></span><a href="https://blog.logrocket.com/when-and-when-not-to-use-redux-41807f29a7fb/" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="487d99cc136247b797c4fe5442515d0a" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="f501634382a042d18321d4730bede5a5"><span data-offset-key="f501634382a042d18321d4730bede5a5:0">might still work well without Redux</span></span></span></a><span key="58affd38fa604e8c886dbc77ac386396"><span offset-key="58affd38fa604e8c886dbc77ac386396:0">.</span></span>

<span key="09486d4a8abe4f9badc9d10ecefe666d"><span offset-key="09486d4a8abe4f9badc9d10ecefe666d:0">One major benefit of Redux is to add direction to decouple â€œwhat happenedâ€ from â€œhow things change.â€ However, you should only implement Redux if you determine your project needs a state management tool. </span></span><a href="javascript:(function()%7B%20f=&#39;https://www.addtoany.com/share#url=&#39;+encodeURIComponent(window.location.href)+&#39;&amp;title=&#39;+encodeURIComponent(document.title);%20a=function()%7B%20if(!window.open(f,&#39;addtoany&#39;,&#39;width=800,height=600,toolbar=yes,location=yes,directories=yes,status=yes,menubar=yes,scrollbars=yes,resizable=yes&#39;))%7B%20location.href=f+&#39;jump=yes&#39;;%20%7D;%20if(/Firefox/.test(navigator.userAgent))%7B%20setTimeout(a,0)%20%7D%20else%7B%20a()%20%7D%20%7D)()" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="bf4540e897ff4341adbbc850f8c188cd" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="569155c45e184828be3f586e7432635c"><span data-offset-key="569155c45e184828be3f586e7432635c:0">Drag to Bookmarks to add to Bookmarks!</span></span></span></a><span key="1da1873ff7874929bb34fddbe04fc17b"><span offset-key="1da1873ff7874929bb34fddbe04fc17b:0"> â‰¡Data Structures Practice Site</span></span><a href="https://trusting-dijkstra-4d3b17.netlify.app" class="css-4rbku5 css-1dbjc4n r-1loqt21 r-1471scf r-1otgn73 r-1i6wzkk r-lrvibr"><span data-key="22a046a130e346378e42514a399d5810" data-rnw-int-class="nearest_257-21750_259-21751-237__"><span data-key="4009a4ed80f447048f0a379587c7f939"><span data-offset-key="4009a4ed80f447048f0a379587c7f939:0">Web Dev Quizzes ?</span></span></span></a><span key="881f10b6856547e5b6516b0e677fe07c"><span offset-key="881f10b6856547e5b6516b0e677fe07c:0">ConnectFollowConnect</span></span>
